description.narrative: NGO Group/CRIN aim to improve implementation of the Convention of the Right of the Child. The contribution is to NGO Group, cooperating with CRIN in a joint application. The focus is networking and a platform function to increase capacity of its member organisations and advocate for child rights.

NGO Group/CRIN verkar för implementering av barnkonventionen. Stöd utgår till NGO Group som samarbetar med CRIN, utgående från en gemensam ansökan. Verksamheten är nätverkande, plattformsfuntion för både kapacitetsutveckling av medlemsorganisationer och påverkansarbete.

description.narrative:
Övergripande fråga: Resultat kopplat till avsedd effekt 2015Fråga: Sammanfatta resultat relaterade till avsedd effekt (denna information kommer att skickas till Open Aid).Svar: First, for this contribution it is important to clarify that Child Rights Connect (CRC) and Child Rights International organisation (CRIN) are two separate organisations that together form part of this one contribution. More of this will be explained later in this finalising memo. When reading this memo therefore keep in mind that the assessments will be done separately of the two organisations.
CRC has during 2015 undergone a very important internal-change process based on the recommendations from the Sida evaluation conducted during the year. The result has been a re-organised secretariat, a clarified theory of change and development of a new conceptualisation of the programmes. Because of this there are semantic deviations from the original proposal submitted (results have been reworded etc) in comparison to the annual report submitted 2015. However the content, thematic activities and overall objective of the organisation has not changed. The theory of change is logic and clearly describe the organisations programmes and theory on how to create change and sustainability. The three programmes 1) Empowering children rights defenders 2) working with the UN and 3) increasing the impact on the national level have continued to be implemented according to plan. Examples of results have been: capacity building of NHRC and the european network of stateless peoples and a strategic partnership has been formed with ICC. 79 children spoke in front of the Committee of the Rights of the Child and provided first-hand information to their experiences, 40 UPR recommendation have been accepted after CRC members submission. CRC continue to work with mainstreaming of children rights at different UN forums, debates, treaty bodies committees etc. CRC and its partners where also highly instrumental working with the HRC resolution "preserving the rights of the child as individuals in family environment". At the debate phase they succeeded in improving the text, however the resolution remains problematic and CRC will continue to work on the issue. CRC and partners continued to lobby national governments and 8 new states have ratified the OP3 CRC. The 6 CRC working groups (part of the CRC network) continued to lobby key UN mechanisms on thematic issues and there are several examples where their work has managed to influence recommendations to states in treaty bodies and other UN related forums.
CRIN has continued their work to advocated for childrens right, in particular areas as monitoring violations of children on a global level, legal advocacy, networking, capacity building and campaigning. One of CRINs value added is that they work particularly on areas that are not set high on the political agenda, ei neglected areas, such as juvenile justice, death penalty etc. CRIN also continue to put a lot emphasis on the access to justice programme, litigations and the rights perspective. In terms of results CRIN monitor the human rights situation for children worldwide and lobby institutions such as African Union, IAHRS (inter-america human rights , EU etc. At current they are also developing a mapping of global advocacy around UN, peacekeeping and sexual abuse. This is something Sida sees as a clear result once finalised in late 2016. Other examples includes; CRIN work in Pakistan, trying to revert death penalty sentencing of people who committed crimes as minors. However not successful at the court cases during 2015. This is an example of important work carried out that in the long term will bring light and start debate on the issue if continued in a systematic way.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
